t: Proverbs 17
Contrast the Upright and the Wicked
Better*pn is a dry morsel and quietness with it Than*ln a house full of feasting with strife.
A*ln servant who acts wisely will rule over a son who acts shamefully, And*ln will share in the inheritance among brothers.
The*ln refining pot is for silver and the furnace for gold, But*ln the Lord*s tests hearts.
An*ln evildoer listens to wicked lips; A*ln liar pays attention to a destructive tongue.
He*ln who mocks the poor taunts his Maker; He*ln who rejoices at calamity will not go unpunished.
Grandchildren*ln are the crown of old men, And*ln the glory of sons is their fathers.
Excellent*ln speech is not fitting for a fool, Much*ln less are lying lips to a prince.
A*ln bribe is a charm in the sight of its owner; Wherever*ln he turns, he prospers.
He*ln who conceals a transgression seeks love, But*ln he who repeats a matter separates intimate friends.
A*ln rebuke goes deeper into one who has understanding Than*ln a hundred blows into a fool.
A*ln rebellious man seeks only evil, So*ln a cruel messenger will be sent against him.
Let*ln a man meet a bear robbed of her cubs, Rather*ln than a fool in his folly.
He*ln who returns evil for good, Evil*ln will not depart from his house.
The*ln beginning of strife is like*i letting out water, So*ln abandon the quarrel before it breaks out.
He*ln who justifies the wicked and he who condemns the righteous, Both*ln of them alike are an abomination to the Lord.*s
Why*ln is there a price in the hand of a fool to buy wisdom, When*ln he has no sense?
A*ln friend loves at all times, And*ln a brother is born for adversity.
A*ln man lacking in sense pledges And*ln becomes guarantor in the presence of his neighbor.
He*ln who loves transgression loves strife; He*ln who raises his door seeks destruction.
He*ln who has a crooked mind finds no good, And*ln he who is perverted in his language falls into evil.
He*ln who sires a fool does*i so*i to his sorrow, And*ln the father of a fool has no joy.
A*ln joyful heart is good medicine, But*ln a broken spirit dries up the bones.
A*ln wicked man receives a bribe from the bosom To*ln pervert the ways of justice.
Wisdom*ln is in the presence of the one who has understanding, But*ln the eyes of a fool are on the ends of the earth.
A*ln foolish son is a grief to his father And*ln bitterness to her who bore him.
It*ln is also not good to fine the righteous, Nor*iln to strike the noble for their*i uprightness.
He*ln who restrains his words has knowledge, And*ln he who has a cool spirit is a man of understanding.
Even*ln a fool, when he keeps silent, is considered wise; When*ln he closes his lips, he is considered*i prudent.
